facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 138 of 1970 before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 138 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 4th May 1970 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1649 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: From the judgment and order dated the 4th May 1970 of the Allahabad High Court at Allahabad in Criminal Revision No. 1649 of 1968.

facts.text: Appellant convicted under Section 60(a) of the U.P. Excise Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was convicted under Section 60 a of the U.P. Excise Act and sentenced to six months rigorous imprisonment

facts.text: Appellant sentenced to six months rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 1000, in default two months imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: and sentenced to six months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1000/-, and, in default of payment of the fine, to undergo imprisonment for a further period of two months.

facts.text: Conviction and sentence confirmed by Sessions Judge and Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: His conviction and sentence were confirmed by the Sessions Judge as well as by the High Court of Allahabad.

facts.text: On 27-10-1967 at about 6.45 p.m., appellant found by raiding Excise staff in a room of a bungalow in Meerut preparing something with seized materials.

anchor.surface_text: On 27-10-1967, at about 6.45 p.m., he was found by the raiding Excise staff in a room of a bungalow in Meerut apparently preparing something with the aid of materials found there which were seized.

facts.text: Seized: Five drums each containing about 20 liters liquor of O.P. strength, samples taken in five bottles from each.

anchor.surface_text: These were said to be Five drums, each containing about 20 liters liquor of O.P. strength, the sample whereof was taken in five bottles from each tin.

facts.text: Seized: Three empty drums of five gallons capacity.

anchor.surface_text: Three empty drums of five gallons capacity. Thirty empty bottles bearing labels.

facts.text: Seized: Thirty empty bottles bearing labels, 120 labels bearing words Khodys Hercules, 142 capsules.

anchor.surface_text: Thirty empty bottles bearing labels. Labels. 120 in number, bearing the words Khodys Herecules . Different types of capsules, 142 in number.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded no concern with bungalow and not present during search.

anchor.surface_text: His plea was that he had no concern with the bungalow in question and that he was not present at the time when its search was taken.

facts.text: Appellant claimed working as salesman in liquor shop of Gyan Chand Chander Mohan in Sadar Bazar, Meerut.

anchor.surface_text: He said that the Excise Inspector came to the liquor shop of Gyan Chand Chander Mohan. situated in Sadar Bazar. Meerut, where he was working as a salesman.

facts.text: Appellant alleged Excise Inspector demanded register, abused him and falsely implicated.

anchor.surface_text: According to him, the Excise Inspector wanted to check the stock of spirit and, demanded the register from him. As the register was locked in a drawer the Excise Inspector is alleged to have abused the appellant and implicated him falsely

facts.text: Search of bungalow No. 243, Circular Road, Meerut Cantonment after search warrant Ex. Ka.1 under Section 52 U.P. Excise Act by First Class Magistrate on 26-10-1967.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned here that the search of bungalow No. 243, Circular Road, Meerut Cantonment, from where the recovery was made, was taken after the issue of a regular search warrant  Ex. Ka. 1  under Section 52 of the U.P. Excise Act, 1910, by a First Class Magistrate on 26-10-1967.

facts.text: Recovery Memo Exhibit Ka.2 dated 27-10-1967 signed by six witnesses, officer and appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The very detailed recovery Memo  Exhibit Ka. 2  dated 27-10- 1967 was signed by as many as six witnesses, in addition to having been signed by the officer who conducted the search and by the appellant himself.

facts.text: Test report in recovery memo showed OP strength for each drum: Drum 1 50.9 OP, Drum 2 50.7, Drum 3 50.6, Drum 4 50.2, Drum 5 50.5.

anchor.surface_text: Test report of the liquor. The contents of all the five  paper torn  of dirty white colour like,  paper torn  characteristics smell of the  paper torn  Hydrometer test is as under  paper torn  Drum No. 1-77 F x 13.2-50.9 O.P. Drum No. 2-77 F x 13.4-50.7 O.P. Drum No. 3-76 F x 13.8-50.6 O.P. Drum No. 4-76 F x 14.2-50.2 O.P. Drum No. 5-77 F x 13.6-50.5 O.P.

facts.text: Appellant professed ignorance about nature of liquid recovered.

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen from the statement of the appellant under Section 342 Criminal Procedure Code that he had professed ignorance about the nature of the liquid recovered from. the room of the house in which he was found.

facts.text: Appellant was employee in a liquor shop.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, the appellant, who was an employee in a liquor shop, could not be so ignorant about the nature of the liquid recovered

facts.text: In Trial Court, appellant examined witnesses to show not present at house but taken from shop.

anchor.surface_text: In the Trial Court, he examined a number of witnesses to substantiate his plea that he was not present at the house from which the recovery was made but was taken from the shop in Sadar Bazar.

facts.text: Main question in Trial Court and Sessions Judge: whether arrested from shop in Sadar Bazar or from Kothi at Circular Road, Meerut Cantt.

anchor.surface_text: And, that was the only question of fact which seems to have been raised and considered in the Trial Court at considerable length. Before the Sessions Judge also the main question raised was whether the at was arrested from the shop in Sadar Bazar or from the Kothi at Cir- cular Road, Meerut Cantt.

facts.text: Sessions Judge distinguished State of Andhra Pradesh v. Madiga Boosenna on ground that Excise Inspector used litmus paper, hydrometer, thermometer, not just smelling.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge, had distinguished Boosennas case  supra  on the ground that the Excise Inspector in the case before us, who had the required technical knowledge and training behind him, had tested the contents of the drums with the aid of litmus paper, hydrometer, and thermometer and not confined himself to smelling the contents of the drums.

facts.text: Questions on smelling test sufficiency and Excise Inspector as expert raised before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that both the questions formulated above were raised before the High Court when the appellants revision application came up before it.

facts.text: High Court held Excise Inspector C.D. Misra PW1 was senior incharge of raids, opinion admissible as expert.

anchor.surface_text: the Excise Inspector C. D. Misra, P.W. 1, was a senior man incharge of raids and detection of important cases so that his opinion evidence was admissible, presumably as expert evidence, and could be relied upon.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Article 134(1)(c) of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In certifying the case under Article 134 1   c  of the Constitution,

facts.text: Excise Inspector C.D. Misra had 21 years service, tested lacs of samples of liquor and illicit liquor.

anchor.surface_text: We find that the Excise Inspector who had deposed, at the very outset of his evidence, that he had put in 21 years service as Excise Inspector and had tested lacs of samples of liquor and illicit liquor.

facts.text: Appellant's counsel cross-examined Excise Inspector only on possession, not on composition, strength or competence.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, the appellants Counsel cross-examined Shri C. D. Misra, W. 1, Excise Inspector, at considerable length, but the whole of this cross-examination was directed at showing that the recoveries were not made from the possession of the appellant. No question was put to him in cross-examination to suggest that the appellant questioned the composition or strength of the liquid recover-

facts.text: No defence evidence led to indicate liquid could be anything else.

anchor.surface_text: Again, no defence evidence was led to indicate that the liquid could be anything else.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal and affirmed conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, we dismiss this appeal and affirm the conviction and sentence of the appellant. The appellant should surrender to his bail and serve out the sentence.
The appellant was convicted under Section 60 a of the U.P. Excise Act and sentenced to six months rigorous imprisonment

issues.text: whether the smelling test employed by the Excise Inspector together with other circumstances were enough to justify the conclusion that the liquid recovered was illicit liquor of O.P strength

anchor.surface_text: And, secondly, whether the Excise Inspector could be considered an expert whose opinion about the nature of the liquid found was opinion evidence admissible under Section 45 of the Evidence Act ?

issues.text: whether the Excise Inspector, whose evidence was under consideration, had sufficient knowledge to be deemed to be an expert within the meaning of Section 45 of the Evidence Act so that the tests adopted by him, together with all the attendant circumstances, could establish beyond doubt that the appellant was in possession of illicit liquor

anchor.surface_text: Another question before us is whether the Excise Inspector, whose evidence was under consideration, had sufficient knowledge to be deemed to be an expert within the meaning of Section 45 of the Evidence Act so that the tests adopted by him, together with all the attendant circumstances, could establish beyond doubt that the appellant was in possession of illicit liquor.

arguments.claim: Boosenna confined to its facts; not applicable here.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, observe that we agree with the High Court that the proposition contained in Boosennas case  supra  must be confined to its own facts.

arguments.claim: Appellant, liquor shop employee, professed ignorance implausible; false defence shows knowledge.

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen from the statement of the appellant under Section 342 Criminal Procedure Code that he had professed ignorance about the nature of the liquid recovered from. the room of the house in which he was found. The false defence taken, that he was not present at the house in question when it was searched, could indicate that he wanted to keep his distance from the recoveries made as he was aware of their incriminating nature.

arguments.claim: Hydrometer test sufficient for strength once alcohol presence known; smelling + instruments adequate.

anchor.surface_text: satisfactorily established that the objects recovered from the possession of the accused included liquor of prohibited strength. Learned Counsel for the appellant had cited State v. Madhukar Gopinath Lalge 2  where it was held in a prosecution under Bombay Prohibition Act, that, although, the circumstances in which an accused was discovered carrying liquid in rubber tubes may raise grave suspicion against him,

holdings.text: It is not desirable to lay down an inflexible rule on questions of fact even though their determination requires the adoption of scientific methods and tests. It is really for the Court of fact to decide whether upon a consideration of the totality of the facts in a case it has been satisfactorily established that the objects recovered from the possession of the accused included liquor of prohibited strength.

anchor.surface_text: We think that it is number desirable to lay down an inflexible rule on questions of fact even though their determination requires the adoption of scientific methods and tests. It is really for the, Court of fact to decide whether upon a companysideration of the totality of the facts in a case. it has been satisfactorily established that the objects recovered from the possession of the accused included liquor of prohibited strength.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Courts should not mandate inflexible scientific tests for factual determinations like substance identity; totality of evidence, including smell, instruments, context, and lack of rebuttal, suffices case-by-case.

holdings.text: This particular Excise Inspector could be treated as an expert within the meaning of Section 45 of the Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore,, think that this particular Excise Inspector companyld be treated as an expert within the meaning of Section 45 of the Evidence Act. The Excise Inspector had, in addition to employing the smelling test, used all the other tests he companyld reasonably adopt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 21 years service, tested lacs of samples, rigorous training per manuals, senior raid incharge, competence unchallenged in cross-examination or defence evidence.

holdings.text: The smelling test employed by the Excise Inspector together with other circumstances including hydrometer, litmus, thermometer tests were enough to justify the conclusion that the liquid recovered was illicit liquor of O.P. strength.

anchor.surface_text: Firstly, whether the smelling test employed by the Excise Inspector together with other circumstances were enough to justify the companyclusion that the liquid recovered was illicit liquor of O.P strength ? And, secondly, whether the Excise Inspector companyld be companysidered an expert whose opinion about the nature of the liquid found was opinion evidence admissible under Section 45 of the. Evidence Act ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Multiple tests used beyond smell, corroborated by seized bottling materials, appellant's liquor experience, signed recovery memo, no rebuttal evidence, false denial indicating knowledge.

holdings.text: The proposition contained in Boosennas case supra must be confined to its own facts.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, observe that we agree with the High Court that the proposition companytained in Boosennas case  supra  must be companyfined to its own facts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished due to additional tests (litmus, hydrometer, thermometer), expert experience, and surrounding circumstances absent in Boosenna.

holdings.text: The Excise Inspector, whose evidence was under consideration, had sufficient knowledge to be deemed to be an expert within the meaning of Section 45 of the Evidence Act so that the tests adopted by him, together with all the attendant circumstances, could establish beyond doubt that the appellant was in possession of illicit liquor.

anchor.surface_text: Another question before us is whether the Excise Inspector, whose evidence was under companysideration, had sufficient knowledge to be deemed to be an expert within the meaning of Section 45 of the Evidence Act so that the tests adopted by him, together with all the attendant circumstances, companyld establish beyond doubt that the appellant was in possession of illicit liquor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Experience, unchallenged tests, no defence evidence disputing composition or competence, totality establishes possession of illicit liquor.

holdings.text: We dismiss this appeal and affirm the conviction and sentence of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, we dismiss this appeal and affirm the companyviction and sentence of the appellant. The appellant should surrender to his bail and serve out the sentence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All issues resolved against appellant; proof of possession and illicit nature established under Section 60(a) U.P. Excise Act.

holdings.text: The appellant was found in possession at the bungalow, not the shop; defence of arrest from shop rejected.

precedents.citation: State of Andhra Pradesh Madiga Boosenna Ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: State of Andhra Pradesh Madiga Boosenna Ors.  1  The learned Sessions Judge, had distinguished Boosennas case  supra  on the ground that the Excise Inspector in the case before us, who had the required technical knowledge and training behind him, had tested the companytents of the drums with the aid of litmus paper, hydrometer, and thermometer and number companyfined himself to smelling the companytents of the drums.

precedents.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Madiga Boosenna Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: smelling test by officers insufficient to prove substance is liquor without scientific proof
precedents.cited_holding: Merely trusting to the smelling sense of the prohibition officers, and basing a conviction, on an opinion expressed by those officers, under the circumstances, cannot justify the conviction of the respondents. In our opinion, better proof by a technical person... is not only desirable, but even necessary

anchor.surface_text: State v. Madhukar Gopinath Lalge 2  where it was held in a prosecution under Bombay Prohibition Act, that, although, the circumstances in which an accused was discovered carrying liquid in rubber tubes may raise grave suspicion against him, yet, the Court would number be companytent with anything less than a chemical or Ido-form test to determine the companyposition of the liquid.

precedents.cited_proposition: chemical or Ido-form test required to prove presence of alcohol; hydrometer test only for strength once alcohol confirmed
precedents.cited_holding: the Court would number be companytent with anything less than a chemical or Ido-form test to determine the companyposition of the liquid. It was held that the Sykes or the Hydrometer test companyld number help in determining whether the liquid under companysideration there really companytained alcohol

anchor.surface_text: Ram Jus v. State  1 , where a Division. Bench of the Allahabad High Court had held that evidence based on chemical analysis was essential in order to establish that a substance-alleged to be Ganja, recovered from an accused person, was really Ganja.

precedents.cited_proposition: chemical analysis essential to prove substance is ganja
